posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
This determined young person is a charming fellow. He wants to become a great mage. He is wise enough to understand that he has great magic talent, but alas, he is not smart enough to realise how to best pursue his goals.
When he starts studying for wizard, he has already learned how to use simple magic devices and how to scribe scrolls. He sits up at night reading in the magical light he conjures - while his bat is out flying, doing whatever bats do.
When he passes the first wizard graduation, he is well paid. Suddenly he can cast light more often. It does not bother him that he cannot figure out yet how to cast the more advanced spells. He probably just has to study much harder.
As he keeps studying, his lore becomes formidable. He becomes widely known for his knowledge and his ability to identify the rarest items.
At some crucial stage, his work pays off. All the efforts have made him brighter and he understands basic spell casting. Now he soon learns to identify things with the help of magic. He also learns how to make his light silent so he can sit up longer reading when his fellow students have gone to sleep. He also learns how to summon animals that can play with his bat familiar.
He firmly believes that a mage never should need to carry a weapon, but rely on his own natural abilities when in trouble. He is a determined fellow and reads some books on oriental martial arts, just to be prepared.

Please enjoy the career of

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hey Mick!

"Nice" build

This reminds me of a campaign i played with a really strict DM. He didn't use Point Distribution cuz he said all characters looked alike, he preferred rolling 3d6 to get starting stats and he wouldn't allow you to reroll. Anyway, my stats weren't as bad, but one of my mates got REALLY unlucky in his rolls so that his higher attribute was 13 and he got all odd number too. He then made a Fighter out of it, putting 13 on Strength and a 12 on Constitution and the result was "CALVIN, THE PEASANT HERO!" He was actually able to survive all the way to level eight, where he perished due to a poor sense of profession and an unrealistic view of his own talents.

Thanks for bringing back these fond memories of my PnP days.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: hunearo
posts.content:
Haha Max, really a nice story :D
My only PnP experience was a half-elf ranger a few years ago. I had no problem with my stats (we rolled 4d6 and the worst dice was removed), but one time I had an end-of-the-day encounter with a lone wolf at the edge of a village where I almost died. I was around lvl 8-9, naturally a wolf is not a problem for a ranger at that level, but I constantly rolled between 1-3 for attack, and that wolf between 15-20, also had a crit once... when my HP fell to 0, the DM said that I regained my conciousness in an unfamiliar room, my whole body was in pain, and I couldn't even sit up properly. Soon a very old women came to the room, and when I asked her about what happened, she said laughing that she saw the whole "battle". When she realized that I didn't play with that wolf and I was in real trouble, she came out to me and chased away that poor animal with a broom and dragged my uncoscious body to her home, and actually she saved my life:D

By the way Mick, you can't take that ESpF: Conjuration at lvl36, Greater SpF is a prereq for it :)

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I have to admit that I never actually played this character all the way to 40, a thing I normally do with every build i post here. Hence an illegal feat snuck in. I have corrected it now.
I did try to play the build once to level 5 or 6 in the Aielund campaign. It was a pain to level it, not so much because of problems with earning XP, but more so because of the feat and skill choices I had to force myself to pick at level up. The best I could do with the character was to play as a terrible support character in a party. The character can use both bard- and wizard gear and can cast from scrolls and class items - and has no problem, whatsoever, with identifying items. Now the challege is on: Can anybody play this character to epic levels, or even to 40? If I should ever want to play it, I would probably take it to a RP PW where you can live a slow life and gather RP xp from talking to other characters. But even then I would probably make the build less awkward.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
I must admit I never took this build seriously when gleaning the particulars for search-ability, Mick.

Still, it's a beacon to all about ability and feat selection when it comes to designing for roleplay.  Truly inspirational and, IMO, well worth the effort in posting it, even as a gag.  It's good to see others are still dissecting it for viability (*staring obliquely at hunearo* ).

With enough dedication from a sympathetic group of fellow party members, I have no doubt the concept would "bloom" into its full potential.  UMDers in the collective would also appreciate the valuable pots and wands which their pointy-eared compatriot can supply when he is not self-indulged, buried in arcane texts.  But solo?  Only masochists need apply.
